subject: statistics
title: CI for Mean with Known Variance
contentHtml:
The Z-interval is a fundamental concept in statistical inference used to construct confidence intervals (CIs) for the population mean when the variance is known.

This formula provides a precise estimate of the population mean within a certain margin of error.
name: Z-interval" },
problemHtml: Suppose we want to estimate the average height of adults in a certain city, with known variance. We take a random sample of size 36 and calculate the mean height to be 175.2 cm.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Define the parameters", "mathHtml": "\(n = 36, \bar{x} = 175.2, \sigma = 5.4\)", "explanation": "We know the sample size, mean height, and variance from our data."} ],
finalAnswer: The estimated population mean is between 173.8 cm and 176.6 cm" },
intuition: The Z-interval formula provides a way to quantify the uncertainty in our estimate of the population mean by incorporating the known variance.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, this concept is crucial for constructing confidence intervals around model predictions.
